channel.title: The Dear Leader, Kim Jong il has sadly passed away
channel.description:
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16239693
North Korean leader Kim Jong-il has died at the age of 69, state-run television has announced. His death was announced in an emotional statement read out on national television. The announcer, wearing black, said he had died on Saturday of physical and mental over-work. The BBC's Lucy Williamson in Seoul says his death will cause huge shock waves across North Korea. Kim Jong-il has been the leader of the impoverished communist country since the death of his father Kim Il-sung in 1994. He suffered a stroke in 2008 and was absent from public view for several months. His designated successor is believed to be his third son, Kim Jong-woon, who is thought to be in his late 20s.
:(

item.title: The Dear Leader, Kim Jong il has sadly passed away
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Frell:

So his son already test fired missiles into the ocean before the funereal was even over

That test was probably unrelated. Il’s death has a huge effect on the citizens, but I doubt the military will stop their work because of it.

[quote=“Radeon, post:33, topic:425882”]He obviously died from some illness but his administration are that bad to lie to the whole population telling them that he died from mental and work overload.

The crying is obviously fake, either they forced them to do that or they paid them to.

This guy is the Pharaoh of the 21st century. He literally has his people worshipping him.[/quote]

You have to realize that their lives depended on Kim Jong Il, or at least that was how they perceived it. He really was a god to them, which isn’t a big surprise because a divine leader is a key part of Stalinism.

Read full topic

item.title: The Dear Leader, Kim Jong il has sadly passed away
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“tL, post:13, topic:425882”][quote author=Cbot link=topic=528564.msg3854954#msg3854954 date=1324268060]
It is pretty sad that North Koreans actually praise him. They should have a revolution in this confusion!
[/quote]

They’re forced to praise him, or they’re carted off to detention camps. They’re starved of outside contact, they know little of the outside world, and of course, they tightly control the little available food in the country.[/quote]
Any country that aren’t able to trade will get problems. What would happen if suddenly no oil-producing country would trade with US? The country would fall in weeks.

I guess NK would be better with a new leader, since it seems like their problem is Kim Jong il and not “communism”/socialism.

Picture of two women with flowers by the North-Korean ambassy in Bejing:

I guess you can like him of your own free will.

And Stalin (More Hitler than Hitler according to some retards) is the third most popular Russian: http://www.reuters.com/article/2008/12/28/us-russia-stalin-idUSTRE4BR17620081228
So it is bullshit to claim people only like a dictator because they are forced to.

Read full topic
